Patch Workflows - Ry‚Äôs Git Tutorial - RyPress -- Another good blog post on working with Git patches via Email as well as applying them. -- The key point (I think) is that you need to grab the entire contents of email email in order in order to pipe the contents into git am - -- Hmmm ü§î -- I think we can do better than this...

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I forget who it was but someone here pushed back on me when I said there were a bunch of Nazi instances on mastodon, but it's true. They were one of the earliest adopters and they're still a big nuisance over there. If yarn ever becomes super popular watch out!

@eaplmx To be honest I would prefer that we define things in terms of the problems they sought out to solve. If someone wants to throw up an issue to start the discussion, we can document this with the builtin pages of yarnd like in https://twtxt.net/help and in the up and coming docs.yarn.social. For reference yarnd has these controls that are noteworthy:

  • Ephemeral Twts and Yarns (with its cache design, posts are not displayed premaritally on your Timeline or on the Discover view or Front page)
  • Muting Feeds: You can mute feeds on a per-user basis
  • Muting Twts and Yarns: You can mute single Twts or entire Yarns (by their hash) on a per-User basic
  • And finally, full URI patterns of feeds/domains can be ‚Äúshadow banned‚Äù on a Pod basis (which has the effect of filtering out Twts from those feeds/users from the Discover view / Front page, but not from users that directly follow them)

@eaplmx To be honest I would prefer that we define things in terms of the problems they sought out to solve. If someone wants to throw up an issue to start the discussion, we can document this with the builtin pages of yarnd like in https://twtxt.net/help and in the up and coming docs.yarn.social. For reference yarnd has these controls that are noteworthy:

Ephemeral Twts and Yarns (with its cache design, posts are not displayed premaritally on your Timeline or on the Discover view or Front page)

Muting Feeds: You can mute feeds on a per-user basis

Muting Twts and Yarns: You can mute single Twts or entire Yarns (by their hash) on a per-User basic

And finally, full URI patterns of feeds/domains can be ‚Äúshadow banned‚Äù on a Pod basis (which has the effect of filtering out Twts from those feeds/users from the Discover view / Front page, but not from users that directly follow them)

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I forget who it was but someone here pushed back on me when I said there were a bunch of Nazi instances on mastodon, but it's true. They were one of the earliest adopters and they're still a big nuisance over there. If yarn ever becomes super popular watch out!

Btw‚Ä¶ I‚Äôd like to take this opportunity to mention my strong feelings of the fact that Twts/Yarns disappear from pods (on purpose) and have what I thought were pretty sensible defaults (maybe those defaults could be collectively reevaluated?) ‚Äì Looking at my own ‚ÄúMuted‚Äù list I note that I still have 9 muted Twts and 3 Muted feeds. I could probably cleanup the Muted Twts (as they‚Äôve probably archived into Bolivian by now, the reason this feature is so important)

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I forget who it was but someone here pushed back on me when I said there were a bunch of Nazi instances on mastodon, but it's true. They were one of the earliest adopters and they're still a big nuisance over there. If yarn ever becomes super popular watch out!

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci Yup makes sense. We had to build pod-level tools for that, which behave the same way as the per-User muting of a Twt or Feed. It was tough to build and I actually learned something new when doing so with the community‚Äôs help üòÖ (although I don‚Äôt like to advertise the feature capability, look at Settings -> Poderator Settings yourself)

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci ‚Äúactive moderators‚Äù and ‚Äúinvested in maintaining the community‚Äù and ‚Äúgood tools‚Äù ‚Äì not to be confused with ‚Äúcensorship‚Äù right? ü§î

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic I think this is the sort of thing that should probably be discussed elsewhere, so as not to leave a convenient roadmap for how to abuse it published right on-site. It should almost certainly involve as many voices as possible, too. I have strong opinions and a particular bias but it's a big, diverse topic.

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci We can rise an issue then üëå

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @abucci Oh it got really bad IMO. I left the community as a result of the disgusting shit I was seeing out of the bitreich.org folks ü§Ø

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci Yup, its appalling really. I‚Äôve only ever met one such person in real-life and boi was that fun ü§Ø (NOT!) ü§£

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic hey guys, I'm randomly joining the convo before breakfast.

@eaplmx Yes! (And good morning!) üëå I have a funny feeling as we continue to grow (slowly) we‚Äôll have to prioritise the ‚ÄúInvite System‚Äù we plan to build for Yarn pods‚Ä¶ Users of other clients are mostly unaffected (single users / feeds).

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I forget who it was but someone here pushed back on me when I said there were a bunch of Nazi instances on mastodon, but it's true. They were one of the earliest adopters and they're still a big nuisance over there. If yarn ever becomes super popular watch out!

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci

We saw a glimpse of this already, with the guy who ‚Äúsoft doxxed‚Äù me. Imagine if 90% of yarn users were doing stuff like that all day every day. I‚Äôd certainly leave pretty quickly‚ÄìI don‚Äôt have time for that, and I don‚Äôt have the free time or the inclination to try to fight it.

Yeah I remember, it was a bit of ‚Äútouch and go‚Äù there for us all, but abuse is abuse and as ‚Äútetering on the edge‚Äù it might have been it was inexcusable. I do wonder though why you‚Äôd leave at all? Wouldn‚Äôt you just Unfollow problematic individuals? ü§î You could even just blacklist the world and maybe just whitelist a few known good feeds, maybe pods even (we haven‚Äôt built this). ‚Äì My point is, escaping people like this is probably hard / next to impossible, all we can do is try to help them (assuming they can be helped at all? ü§î I‚Äôm sure some can be helped/saved ü§û), and ensure they don‚Äôt or cannot abuse the platform (or in our case, the ecosystem)‚Ä¶

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci

We saw a glimpse of this already, with the guy who ‚Äúsoft doxxed‚Äù me. Imagine if 90% of yarn users were doing stuff like that all day every day. I‚Äôd certainly leave pretty quickly‚ÄìI don‚Äôt have time for that, and I don‚Äôt have the free time or the inclination to try to fight it.

Yeah I remember, it was a bit of ‚Äútouch and go‚Äù there for us all, but abuse is abuse and as ‚Äútetering on the edge‚Äù it might have been it was inexcusable. I do wonder though why you‚Äôd leave at all? Wouldn‚Äôt you just Unfollow problematic individuals? ü§î You could even just blacklist the world and maybe just whitelist a few known good feeds, maybe pods even (we haven‚Äôt built this). ‚Äì My point is, escaping people like this is probably hard / next to impossible, all we can do is try to help them (assuming they can be helped at all? ü§î I‚Äôm sure some can be helped/saved ü§û), and ensure they don‚Äôt or cannot abuse the platform (or in our case, the ecosystem)‚Ä¶
